美国众议院罢免了凯文·麦卡锡的议长职务，这是历史上第一次有人被罢免。他的垮台是由极右翼国会议员马特·盖茨发起的，此前麦卡锡先生在民主党的支持下确保通过了一项避免政府关门的最后一刻法案（该法案使政府只能运转到 11 月 17 日）。盖兹先生说，这是一次售空。在决定麦卡锡先生命运的投票中，少数叛逆的共和党人与民主党人一起解雇了他。

加利福尼亚州州长加文·纽瑟姆任命拉方扎·巴特勒担任因黛安·范斯坦去世而空缺的参议院席位。范斯坦女士于 1992 年当选为该席位，现年 90 岁，是众议院最年长的议员。巴特勒女士是一名女同性恋，也是有史以来第三位黑人女参议员。她是美国副总统卡马拉·哈里斯的亲密盟友，哈里斯是第二位当选参议员的黑人女性。

唐纳德·特朗普商业欺诈罪的审判在纽约开始。除了对他的民事指控之外，还指控特朗普及其企业夸大其资产价值以获取贷款。法官（没有陪审团）已经裁定特朗普先生在这件事上犯下了“反复且持续的欺诈行为”。

亨特·拜登出席法庭听证会，对非法拥有枪支的指控表示不认罪。

罗伯特·菲科（Robert Fico）希望再次成为斯洛伐克总理，此前他的政党在大选中名列前茅，并寻求组建执政联盟。菲科是一位亲俄罗斯的民粹主义民族主义者，此前曾两度担任总理，并于 2018 年因记者被谋杀引发的大规模抗议而辞职。他承诺停止向乌克兰提供武器。

欧盟外长在乌克兰首都基辅举行会议，这是欧盟外长首次在非欧盟国家举行会议。他们承诺向乌克兰提供更多帮助，但曾经坚定的捍卫乌克兰的支持最近出现了动摇。除了菲科当选外，波兰还与乌克兰在粮食出口问题上发生争执，并且没有向乌克兰提供更多武器。美国共和党人已阻止国会紧急支出计划中向乌克兰提供额外资金。

取消出发

英国首相里希·苏纳克宣布，连接伯明翰和曼彻斯特的高铁项目的一段路段将被取消。 HS2的成本从 2009 年最初的 375 亿英镑（当时为 620 亿美元）飙升至估计的 1000 亿英镑。苏纳克先生认为，这笔钱最好用在北部城市之间的交通连接上。

塞尔维亚表示，在一座修道院发生涉及塞族人和科索沃警察的枪战后，两国关系紧张，该国已撤回部分派往科索沃边境的部队。美国称塞尔维亚的军事集结“非常不稳定”。

在西班牙，保守派人民党领袖阿尔贝托·努涅斯·费霍 (Alberto Núñez Feijóo) 未能组建联合政府，国王责成佩德罗·桑切斯 (Pedro Sánchez) 领导的社会党尝试组建新政府。总理桑切斯先生在 7 月份举行了一场没有结果的选举，人民党在选举中获得了最多席位，但远未达到多数席位。如果他想再次执政，他将需要极左翼以及巴斯克和加泰罗尼亚民族主义政党的支持。

在一名自杀式炸弹袭击者袭击安卡拉内政部后，土耳其对伊拉克北部的库尔德叛乱分子进行了空袭，并逮捕了数十名涉嫌库尔德工人党活动人士。警方击毙了第二名袭击者，但事件没有造成其他死亡。

抗议者封锁了危地马拉的道路，抗议总检察长从选举当局手中扣押选票，这是针对当选总统贝尔纳多·阿雷瓦洛的最新举动。自从反腐败斗士阿雷瓦洛先生在八月份的选举中获胜以来，一群精英一直试图解散他的政党，以阻止他在一月份掌权。

经过一年的争论，联合国安理会投票支持派遣肯尼亚领导的多国武装部队前往海地一年。肯尼亚将派遣1000名士兵，其他国家也承诺提供人员和资金。俄罗斯和中国投了弃权票。过去在这个加勒比岛国的部署并不总是受到当地人的欢迎，但该国的帮派暴力已经达到了绝望的地步。

巴基斯坦清真寺发生两起自杀式炸弹袭击，造成 59 人死亡。没有任何组织声称对此负责，但巴基斯坦政府下令所有非法移民，即 170 万阿富汗人，在 11 月 1 日之前离开该国。 （大约 440 万阿富汗难民也居住在那里。）政府表示，今年巴基斯坦发生的 24 起自杀式爆炸事件中，有 14 起是阿富汗人制造的，并指责阿富汗窝藏肇事组织。

据报道，印度命令加拿大将其 62 名外交官中的 41 人撤出该国，这与加拿大声称印度在温哥华杀害了一名锡克教分裂分子的说法继续存在争议。加拿大总理贾斯汀·特鲁多表示：“我们目前与印度正在经历一个极具挑战性的时期。”

德里警方突击搜查了数十名与进步新闻网站 NewsClick 的资助有关的记者的住所。当局声称 NewsClick 收到了来自中国的非法资金，但该公司对此予以否认。

中国的收获，印度的损失

穆罕默德·穆伊祖 (Mohamed Muizzu) 击败现任总统易卜拉欣·穆罕默德·萨利赫 (Ibrahim Mohamed Solih)，赢得了马尔代夫总统第二轮选举。穆伊祖先生是亲中国的。胜利后，他宣布“外国军队”，即一小群印度士兵，必须离开这个群岛国家。

美国对 25 家中国公司和个人实施制裁，因为他们涉嫌参与生产用于生产芬太尼的化学品。在美国，滥用阿片类药物被认为是造成许多人死亡的原因。中国对这些措施提出抗议，坚称易制毒化学品受到严格控制。

图阿雷格叛军在莫普提中部地区发动袭击，占领了马里北部的一座城镇，并杀死了 80 多名士兵。这是他们自 2015 年签署的和平协议破裂后 8 月爆发战斗以来最南端的一次袭击。新的冲突在一定程度上是由于联合国维和人员的撤出而引发的，这些维和人员被执政军政府下令离开该国。

尼日尔的圣战分子杀死了至少 29 名士兵，这是自 7 月政变以来武装分子发动的最致命的一次袭击。自从民选总统穆罕默德·巴祖姆被推翻以及与法国关系破裂以来，安全局势急剧恶化。法国正在撤回帮助尼日尔打击圣战分子的 1,500 名士兵。

在埃塞俄比亚因提格雷内战期间犯下的暴行而中断援助三年后，欧盟同意向埃塞俄比亚提供 6.5 亿欧元（6.83 亿美元）的援助。联合国专家表示，战争罪行仍在发生。

埃及总统阿卜杜勒-法塔赫·塞西宣布，他将在 12 月的选举中第三次连任。获胜很容易，但他的支持率已经下降，他的下一个任期将面临无数问题，尤其是埃及陷入困境的经济。

伊朗的人权活动家指责德黑兰因未戴头巾而殴打一名乘坐地铁的女孩的道德政策。他们发布了一张照片，称照片显示她处于昏迷状态。伊朗当局称她晕倒了。

由于投资者押注利率将在更长时间内保持较高水平， 政府债券市场的溃败加剧。美国十年期国债收益率接近 4.9%，为 2007 年以来最高水平。在欧洲，德国基准十年期国债收益率自 2011 年以来首次升至 3% 以上。市场猜测日本央行将很快采取行动。加息后，日本债券收益率达到十年来的最高点，迫使央行计划外购买政府债务，以维持控制收益率的政策。在日元兑美元汇率达到 150 美元后，日本财务省拒绝透露是否干预了货币市场。

抛售波及股市，导致道琼斯工业平均指数今年转为负数。标准普尔 500 指数9 月下跌 5%，纳斯达克综合指数下跌 6%，这是这两个指数 2023 年迄今为止表现最差的一个月。

对祖国失去信心

俄罗斯卢布兑美元汇率跌破 100 美元兑 100 美元的象征性关口。克里姆林宫发言人表示“没有理由担心”。官员们一直在向央行施加压力，要求其提高利率以阻止经济下滑。该银行在8月份紧急加息，并于上个月再次将主要利率提高至13%。卢布贬值的一个原因是商人从俄罗斯撤资，这引发了一场关于重新引入俄罗斯对乌克兰战争开始时实施的货币管制类型的争论。

欧元区9月份年度通胀率大幅下降至4.3%，为近两年来的最低水平。不包括食品和能源的核心利率下降至4.5%。欧洲央行的情绪是，它将把利率维持在目前的高水平，以便到 2025 年通胀率降至 2%。

石油成本上涨导致土耳其9 月份通货膨胀率达到 61.5%。央行已将利率提高至 30%，试图抑制物价上涨。

Sam Bankman-Fried因全球第三大加密货币交易所FTX破产而在曼哈顿一家法院受审。班克曼-弗里德被指控在他创立的公司中欺骗投资者和客户以及洗钱。他不认罪。这位前豪赌客曾因慷慨资助与“有效利他主义”相关的项目而受到政客的追捧，预计将持续六周。

Birkenstock即将在纽约证券交易所首次公开募股 (IPO)的定价为每股 44 美元至 49 美元。这家德国凉鞋制造商正在寻求 100 亿美元的最高估值，这将使其成为今年最大的股市上市之一。

随着破产的斯堪的纳维亚航空公司重组业务，法航-荷航将收购SAS 19.9% 的股份。美国私募股权公司Castlelake将成为最大股东，持股32%。丹麦政府将持有大约26%的股份。此次重组意味着SAS将不再在股票市场上市，现有股东将被淘汰。

特斯拉第三季度交付了超过 435,000 辆汽车。即使考虑到汽车制造商工厂升级的影响，这也低于市场预期。由于特斯拉的产量比上一季度下降了 10%，比亚迪正在紧随其后，成为全球最大的电动汽车销售商。这家正在大力进军海外市场的中国公司本季度售出了 431,600 辆纯电动汽车。

乘着旅游业繁荣的浪潮，嘉年华游轮公布了创纪录的 69 亿美元季度收入和稳健的利润。该公司的预订量比 2019 年的水平高出近 20%。嘉年华和皇家加勒比游轮是今年标准普尔 500指数中表现最好的股票之一，仅次于 Meta、Nvidia 和特斯拉等公司。

小偷的天堂

英国零售商要求政府采取紧急行动，制止零售犯罪的上升。截至 2022 年 3 月的 12 个月内，英国商店每天记录了 867 起事故，是大流行前的两倍。在最近的调查中，尽管零售商在预防犯罪方面花费了 7 亿英镑，但零售盗窃造成的损失为 9.53 亿英镑（11 亿美元）。零售商希望警方采取更多行动； 44% 的人认为警方的反应很差。

佛罗伦萨禁止在市中心提供新的短期租赁服务，成为最新一个限制Airbnb和类似平台的旅游目的地。尽管普通住宅月均租金上涨了 42%，但 Airbnb 上挂牌的当地房产数量已从 2016 年的 6,000 处激增至如今的近 14,400 处。市长说，佛罗伦萨人抱怨他们的公寓楼正在变成酒店。

深入探讨本周漫画的主题：
 凯文·麦卡锡的下台：对美国不利，对乌克兰更糟
凯文·麦卡锡被解职加剧美国政府混乱
共和党人开始反对乌克兰

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 12:47:55 GMT /内容/slehqloqcuq252mnrd1maau1l9dsmje1 https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2023/10/05/kals-cartoon This week’s covers

本周我们有两期封面，分别是关于世界上日益占主导地位的大国意识形态和非洲人对民主的幻灭。

《经济学人》成立于 1843 年，其宗旨之一是争取自由贸易和政府发挥适度作用。今天，这些古典自由主义价值观不仅不受欢迎，而且还受到人们的欢迎。他们几乎完全缺席政治辩论。

各国政府认为有必要在许多方面进行干预，包括脆弱的供应链、国家安全日益增长的威胁、能源转型和生活成本危机。这些政策领域中的每一个领域都是人们所熟悉的——事实上，在不同的时期，我们都将它们全部放在了封面上。只有当你把它们放在一起时，你才会明白开放市场和有限政府的假设是多么系统地被抛在了尘埃中。

我们封面的任务是捕捉格式塔，而不屈服于怀旧或一厢情愿的想法。

新政权的核心理念是，保护是应对战争或流行病对开放市场冲击的方法——无论是在设置贸易壁垒的意义上，还是在向家庭发放救济提高了国家期望的意义上充当抵御不幸的堡垒。

我们从集装箱的插图开始，集装箱是全球化的象征。但我们将它们堆叠在一起，形成了延伸到地平线的屏障。这是个好主意，但这座特殊的长城在中国有着强烈的回响——而国家安全只是国家介入的原因之一。

在另一项早期尝试中，我们描绘了一个下降的吊闸，其尖刺是指向下方的箭头，刺穿了“国土经济”一词。这是我们创造的术语，用来描述保护主义、高补贴、重干预国家的意识形态。这是对经济体吊桥向上/吊桥向下分类的认可——但也许正是因为这个原因，文字和图像的组合令人困惑。

所以我们又回到了容器。但这一次，它们是全球化废墟中的废物。沮丧的幸存者坐在山顶上，等待着永远不会到来的救援。这是一幅绝望的景象——在如此绝望的情况下，开放市场的活动家们可能应该弃船而回，埋头于集邮或制作果酱中。

集装箱作为巨石阵的形象达到了更好的平衡。它说全球化时代已经过去，其神秘的仪式和仪式已经被遗忘——这与事实相差不远。不到八年前，巴拉克·奥巴马总统试图让美国签署一项庞大的太平洋贸易协定。今天，如果你在华盛顿主张自由贸易，你会被嘲笑为天真得无可救药。在新兴世界，你将被描绘成西方最了解的时代的新殖民主义遗物。

我们对集装箱巨石的第一个草图可以看出是索尔兹伯里平原某处的一座新自由主义纪念碑，但强烈的对比和完美的直角令人反感。我们的一位德鲁伊派同事还指出，异教徒在黎明时分在萨尔森石中崇拜，而我们的封面线则询问全球化的太阳是否正在落山。我们通过照亮最终图像、将一些集装箱歪斜地放置在草丛中并清楚地说明本土经济的崛起来纠正这一切。我们希望这个黎明是短暂的。

领袖：自由市场是历史吗？
特别报告： 世界各国政府正在发现“本土经济”

许多非洲人对民主失去了信心。民意调查机构 Afrobarometer 发现，相比任何其他形式的政府，更喜欢民主的比例已从 2012 年的 75% 下降至 66%。这听起来似乎是绝对多数，但其中也包括许多摇摆不定的人。令人震惊的 53% 的人表示，如果文职领导人滥用权力（他们经常这样做），政变就是合法的。在拥有世界上最自由宪法之一的南非，72％的人表示，如果非民选领导人能够减少犯罪并促进住房和就业，他们将愿意放弃选举。

民主衰落的衡量标准之一是政变的数量。只关注过去三年内政府被暴力接管推翻的国家，现在你可以一路步行穿越非洲，从大西洋到红海。我们对封面图片的第一次尝试捕捉到了这个悲惨的事实。它描绘了一个拿着枪的男人的剪影，他的头是非洲的形状。然而，政变只是故事的一部分。如果把这一切都写成关于持枪的人，我们会说整个大陆都陷入了火焰之中。

在另一个早期的草图中，我们将标题写成“X”格式，以表明许多非洲国家对民主不再抱有幻想。这涉及到一个重要的点：你可以选择选举一个独裁者，但你可能无法选择投票把他赶下台。然而，它忽略了更深层次的东西。非洲许多所谓的民主国家都是假的。统治者允许反对派参加选举，但采取了上千种预防措施以确保他们无法获胜，从篡改选民名册到限制媒体。从这个意义上说，非洲人根本没有真正对民主说“不”。

然后，我们尝试描绘一只巨大的踩投票箱的靴子，希望它能传达政变和腐败的混合体。但它感觉太笼统了——就好像我们正在调查全世界的民主一样。

最终我们选择了这个封面。这些弹孔巧妙地让人想起政变的暴力和选举过程中的破坏行为。掉头提醒人们这是一个逆转。冷战结束后，许多非洲国家采用了多党民主制。在肯尼亚和赞比亚等一些国家，权力在选民的要求下或多或少和平地易手。

反对民主将给许多非洲人带来贫困和苦难。无法保证一个更加民主的非洲会繁荣与和平，但一个由独裁者和将军统治的非洲肯定不会。

H UMOUR IS A powerful tool, especially on the cover of a current-affairs magazine with a dry-as-sand title like The Economist . The risk of sounding hectoring and stuffily self-important is nicely offset by a cover that does not take itself too seriously.

In 1994, amid a wave of mergers in the United States, we warned that deals were harder to bring off than investors and managers seemed to believe. Unfortunately, humour also risks causing offence. A pair humping camels on the cover of an edition of The Economist from the time got us banned in Saudi Arabia—or at least that is the folk memory here.

This week we have two covers, on the science behind the promise of living to 120, and on the urgent need for the European Union to get bigger. In both cases we were tempted by humour, but ended up playing it straight. See if you think we were right.

For centuries the attempt to stop ageing was the preserve of charlatans touting the benefits of mercury and arsenic, or assortments of herbs and pills, often to disastrous effect. Yet after years of false starts, the idea of a genuine elixir of longevity is taking wing. Should the latest efforts to prolong life reach their potential, living to see your 100th birthday could become the norm; it could be perfectly reasonable to dream of making it to 120.

We started with a birthday cake that can barely accommodate all 120 candles burning brightly on top. The progress that has been made in extending lifespans has so far come by countering the causes of death, especially infectious disease. This time the intention is to slow the process of ageing itself, with its attendant ills such as dementia.

The birthday cake signals not only age but also the fact that there is much to celebrate. But a Google search showed that the cake idea has been used many times before. If the cake was our cover, many readers would feel that we were like a supercentenarian repeating a favourite anecdote—again.

We then tried a more mordant take. A familiar image from British sitcoms is pensioners putting their false teeth in a cup of water at bedtime. Our pensioner is celebrating by plonking them into a glass of bubbly instead.

As our leader explains, living to 120 is still some way off: none of the drugs that promise long-life has yet been tested on people. And even if the body survives, nobody can be sure quite how very old people's minds will bear up—even if they are free of dementia.

Despite that, teeth-in-champagne doesn't quite come off. False teeth are a symbol of decay, but the science is about slowing or preventing senescence rather than living with it.

Put off by the sight of chompers in champers, we looked for something else.

This is the design that we ended up choosing. It has energy, it looks forward and it says that living to 120 opens the door to a very different future. Roughly 150 years ago global life-expectancy at birth was 30. Just imagine how different the supercentenarian world would be.

The horror of two world wars prompted France, West Germany and others to link arms and create what is today the European Union. Seventy years on, war has returned to the continent. Out of the rubble in Ukraine, something akin to the sentiment that moved the EU ’s founding fathers is leading to talk of admitting as many as nine new members, including Ukraine. For the EU itself it would mark the end of a process that started with victory over the Nazis. Bar one or two future applicants (perhaps one day including Britain), the shape of the EU would broadly be settled. But the way the EU works would have to change profoundly.

EU covers can seem distant from readers, threatening them with mind-numbing ruminations about treaty-change and variable geometry. No wonder our designers reached for their tickle-sticks.

They drew up an illustration of Michelangelo's David, with a large gold star from the EU flag covering his genitals. Nobody could accuse this cover of taking itself too seriously. But plenty of us thought that, beyond a play on the word “enlargement”, the number-one target of spam filters the world over, it really had nothing to say about the issues.

Instead we decided to play with the furniture on our cover. Expanding the EU from 27 to, say, 36 will require the union to rethink its inner workings: a bigger EU will not be a better one if it becomes gridlocked. At 36, it would be foolish to allow a single country's government to veto collective action, as is the case now for foreign affairs and taxation. The common agricultural policy, which gobbles up a third of the bloc's budget, will need drastic reform and slimming to stop subsidies flowing to Ukrainian oligarchs running farms the size of some EU countries. Letting in poorer members will shift development funds away from some current recipients.

One idea was for the clumsy word “enlargement” to bust the circle of gold stars that comprises the EU's flag—but that lacked drama. Another was for a single giant star to shunt aside our masthead and the flashes that signal some of the week's highlights—but that was hard to read. In a week of compromises, for our final cover we steered somewhere between the two.

One question is whether we were right to reject the schoolboy humour of the false teeth and Michelangelo's David. A more interesting question is whether, in today's more puritanical world, we could get away with a pair of copulating camels.

Canada 's prime minister, Justin Trudeau, said that Indian agents were behind the killing of a Sikh leader near Vancouver in June. India denied it. Hardeep Singh Nijjar had pushed for a Sikh homeland in India. India says he was a terrorist, Mr Nijjar's supporters say he was a peaceful activist. Mr Trudeau's allegation of a fellow democracy assassinating a Canadian citizen on Canadian soil has ramifications beyond a souring of relations with India. America's National Security Council has said it is “deeply concerned”, and has urged India to co-operate.

India’s MP s held their first session in a new Parliament building, which replaces the old one designed by the British in the 1920s. In May opposition parties protested against its inauguration, accusing Narendra Modi, the prime minister, of turning what was supposed to be a show of national unity into a party rally.

Speculation swirled around China's defence minister , General Li Shangfu, who has not been seen in public for weeks. Some reports suggested that he was under investigation for corruption and would be removed. The episode comes just months after purges of China's foreign minister, Qin Gang, and the leadership of China's Rocket Force, which controls the country's conventional and nuclear missiles.

China's top diplomat , Wang Yi, met America's national-security adviser, Jake Sullivan, in Malta. Among the topics discussed was the war in Ukraine. A day later Mr Wang arrived in Moscow, where he met Russia's president, Vladimir Putin. China claims to be neutral in the war, but its officials repeat Kremlin talking points. Local media said Mr Wang's trip would help pave the way for a visit by Mr Putin to China.

Azerbaijan sent its army into Nagorno-Karabakh , a disputed enclave with a majority Armenian population, in what it described as an “anti-terrorism” operation against “illegal Armenian military formations”. Ethnic Armenians agreed to a ceasefire. Tensions have been running high because of Azerbaijan's blockade of Karabakh, which has led to medicine and fuel shortages.

Volodymyr Zelensky gave a speech in person to the UN General Assembly in New York, in which he warned that Russia is trying to smash the established international order and push the world to a “final war”. The Ukrainian president also compared Russia's abduction of Ukrainian children to “genocide”. Mr Zelensky then went to Washington to discuss further help for Ukraine's war effort.

Hungary, Poland and Slovakia imposed their own curbs on imports of Ukrainian grain , after the European Union lifted a partial ban. As a row over the curbs escalated, Poland said it would no longer supply weapons to Ukraine.

Evika Silina became Latvia’s new prime minister, after forming another coalition headed by the centre-right New Unity party. One of the first tasks of the new government was to close one of Latvia's border points with Belarus following an increase in illegal crossings by migrants.

Greens see red

Rishi Sunak, Britain’s prime minister, announced some changes to the government's plan to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, such as delaying a ban on new petrol cars by five years to 2035. He said this was being done so that the 2050 target could be met in a “better, more proportionate” way. In Sweden the government's budget contained tax-cutting measures, including on fuel duties. Sweden was the first country to lay out an aim of net-zero, but some think the budget means it now won't be able to hit that goal in 2045.

The Italian cabinet approved a measure that extends the time that some migrants can be detained to 18 months. The government is scrambling to respond to a wave of 8,000 migrants who have landed on the tiny Italian island of Lampedusa, a favourite destination for the people-smugglers who traffic migrants in boats from Tunisia, just 113 kilometres (61 miles) away.

Protests broke out against the authorities in Derna, a city in eastern Libya recently devastated by floods. Calls are growing for an international investigation into why the dams in the city burst.

Israeli forces killed six Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Four were killed in a raid on Jenin refugee camp, the scene two months ago of Israel's biggest raid in 20 years. In New York Israel's prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, held a long-awaited meeting with Joe Biden. Mr Biden said the pair had discussed “hard issues”.

One of the leaders of the Free Current coalition in Egypt , the main liberal opposition party, was sentenced to six months in prison for slander and verbally assaulting a police officer. His supporters say the charges were politically motivated and the party has said it will not put up a candidate in Egypt's presidential election due next year.

Iran and America each swapped five prisoners in a deal in which $6bn-worth of frozen Iranian assets, mostly oil revenues, were also released. Shortly after the deal was announced Ebrahim Raisi, Iran's president, addressed the UN assembly, accusing America of inflaming violence in Ukraine. Meanwhile Iranian MP s passed a draft law imposing sentences of up to ten years on women who flout the country's dress code, a year after widespread protests against the killing of Mahsa Amini, a woman who was detained for showing her hair.

The Dominican Republic sealed its border with Haiti after a breakdown in negotiations over using water from the Massacre River. A farmers' group in Haiti is building a canal to irrigate land dried out by drought, but this will divert water from the Dominican Republic, says the country's president, Luis Abinader.

Thousands of Guatemalans demonstrated to demand an end to efforts by officials to hinder the transfer of power to Bernardo Arévalo , who was elected as the country's president in August. Mr Arévalo, a reformist who is due to take office in January, presented a petition asking the Supreme Court to block attempts to overturn his victory.

America's merry-go-round

Kevin McCarthy, the speaker of America's House of Representatives, had another battle on his hands with rebels in his Republican Party, who are once again threatening to shut down the government by refusing to back stopgap funding legislation. Meanwhile, America's gross national debt exceeded $33trn for the first time.

The Texas Senate acquitted Ken Paxton , the state's attorney-general, at his impeachment trial. In May Mr Paxton, a hardline conservative, was impeached by the Texas House of Representatives, which is Republican controlled, for alleged bribery and abuse of public trust.

Paul Kagame, who has been president of Rwanda since 2000 and its de facto leader since toppling a genocidal government in 1994, said he plans to run for a fourth presidential term next year. Mr Kagame pushed through a constitutional change in 2015 that could allow him to stay in power until 2034.

The EU has stopped funding Zimbabwe’s electoral commission, citing concerns about its independence during elections in August. Although the electoral funding is worth just $5m, cutting it may signal a deeper breach with the EU , which had been hoping to mend relations and unlock financial support for Zimbabwe from the World Bank and IMF.

There are “grave and ongoing” violations of human rights taking place in Tigray and other regions of Ethiopia , almost a year since a formal end to its civil war, the UN ’s Human Rights Council said in a report. Many of the ongoing atrocities in Tigray are being committed by soldiers from Eritrea, whose forces were supposed to have withdrawn under the terms of the peace deal.

Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger have signed a mutual-defence pact known as the Alliance of Sahel States ( ASS ). All three members of the ASS are run by military juntas following a series of coups over the past two years.

The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate on hold at a range of between 5.25% and 5.5%, but said it remained “highly attentive to inflation risks”. New forecasts from the central bank suggest that the American economy is proving to be more robust than expected, pointing to another rate rise before the end of the year. Markets don't expect the Fed to start cutting rates until towards the end of next year at the earliest.

The Bank of England also maintained its key interest rate, at 5.25%, ending a run of 14 consecutive rate rises. The bank's decision came a day after figures showed that Britain's annual rate of inflation had unexpectedly slipped to 6.7%. Economists had predicted that the inflation rate would rise because of higher fuel costs, but this was offset by an easing of prices in certain items, including food and hotels.

In its latest projections, the OECD said that the impact of higher interest rates is “becoming increasingly visible”. The organisation upgraded its estimate of world GDP growth this year to 3%, but pared back its forecast for next year to 2.7%. The OECD said that monetary policy needed “to remain restrictive” until inflation is firmly under control, but it warned that the effects of rate rises “will continue to work their way through economies for some time”.

Instacart 's share price rose by 12% on its first day of trading on the Nasdaq exchange. The online-groceries company raised the offer price of its shares to $30, after Arm’s successful IPO on September 14th whetted investors' appetite for more tech offerings. The British chip designer's stock soared by 25% in its debut on the Nasdaq, raising $5bn to make it the biggest IPO in America in two years. But the share prices of both Arm and Instacart fell back in subsequent trading.

Bob van Dijk abruptly resigned as chief executive of Naspers, an internet company based in South Africa, and as the head of Prosus, which is controlled by Naspers and is one of the world's biggest technology-investment firms. Mr Van Dijk had led Naspers for nine years, trying to handle the problematic mismatch between the value of its assets and its share price.

Toshiba’s shareholders approved an offer for the Japanese conglomerate that will take it private. Its management hopes the fresh start will draw a line under years of upheaval. The consortium taking over Toshiba is led by a Japanese private-equity firm, Japan Industrial Partners.

Elemental

Disney announced that it is doubling its investment in its theme parks, cruise line and resorts to $60bn. The company's parks-and-experiences division generates more operating income ($7.6bn for the nine months ending July 1st) than its media and entertainment business ($2.2bn).

California's governor, Gavin Newsom, said he would sign a state bill requiring companies to disclose how much greenhouse gas they directly emit, as well as indirect emissions. They are the toughest measures on climate disclosure in America and will affect around 5,000 companies that do business in the state. Meanwhile California's attorney-general lodged a lawsuit against big oil companies such as BP and ExxonMobil, seeking damages for what it claims is an industry cover-up about the harm that fossil fuels can do.

Oil prices climbed to their highest levels in ten months, as markets fretted that cuts to output by Saudi Arabia and Russia could cause a supply shortfall. Brent crude rose to $95 a barrel for the first time since November. Saudi Arabia's energy minister defended the decision to lower production. It's not about “jacking up prices”, he said, and more to do with economic uncertainties, such as demand in China.

The United Auto Workers union said it would expand its strike to other factories unless there was “serious progress” in talks with Ford, General Motors and Stellantis. The UAW has co-ordinated its action against all three of Detroit's carmakers for the first time, but limited the strike to one plant for each company. Meanwhile Ford reached a tentative deal with its union in Canada to avert a strike there.

China's imports of Japanese seafood fell by 68% in August from the same month last year. China, the world's biggest market for Japanese fish and shellfish, banned the products when Japan released wastewater from the damaged Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea.

It's a family affair

FTX, a bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, sued the parents of its founder, Sam Bankman-Fried , to recover “fraudulently transferred and misappropriated funds” that it claims were paid out to the couple before the company collapsed last November. Mr Bankman-Fried goes on trial on October 3rd charged with fraud related to FTX ’s implosion. A judge sent him to jail in August, accusing him of tampering with witnesses.

Elon Musk described reports that Tesla is in talks to build a factory in Saudi Arabia as “utterly false”. Mr Musk has a complex relationship with the Saudis, caused in large part by what he perceives to be a Saudi failure to back a plan to take Tesla private. “You are throwing me under the bus,” Mr Musk tweeted to the head of the country's sovereign-wealth fund in 2018.
